questions.text: Which data set provides the most comprehensive explanation for the variation between the highest and lowest values?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Range

The range is the simplest measure of variation in a dataset. It is calculated by subtracting the lowest value from the highest value, providing a direct measure of the spread or dispersion of the data.

  • Range = Highest value - Lowest value
  • It gives a clear indication of the overall spread of data from the minimum to the maximum.

Variance (Option A): Variance measures the average squared deviation from the mean. While it indicates the spread of data, it does not directly focus on the highest and lowest values.

Coefficient of Variation (Option B): The coefficient of variation is the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean and expresses the variability relative to the mean. It’s useful for comparing relative variability but doesn't focus on the highest and lowest values.

Interquartile Range (IQR) (Option D): The IQR measures the spread of the middle 50% of the data (between the 25th and 75th percentiles). While it indicates the dispersion of the central portion of the data, it does not address the variation between the highest and lowest values as directly as the range.

questions.text: An intern has to study the relationship between ordering food online and development of obesity using a case-control study. What are the best study groups to be selected?

choices.text: Online food eaters and non-online food eaters

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Obese and non-obese persons:

  • In a case-control study, the cases are those with the condition of interest (in this case, obesity), and the controls are those without the condition (non-obese persons).
  • After selecting these groups, the researcher would look retrospectively to assess the exposure to the risk factor (in this case, ordering food online).
  • This design is ideal for studying the association between a specific exposure and an outcome.

Salient Features of Case-control study

  • Case-control study is an observational, analytical study.
  • Both exposure and outcome have occurred before the start of the study.
  • Control group who do not have the disease and Case group who have contracted the disease.
  • Study precedes backwards from effect to cause, i.e. Outcome is used to determine the cause.

 

Only obese persons, Only online food eaters (Options A and B): do not include a comparison group

Online food eaters and non-online food eaters (Option D): focuses on exposure groups rather than outcome groups, which is not the correct approach for a case-control study.

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Prospective cohort

This involves identifying a cohort of individuals (in this case, pregnant women) and collecting data on exposures (e.g., maternal smoking) during the study period, then following them forward in time to assess outcomes (e.g., birth weight of babies).

  • In this study, smoking history is recorded during antenatal visits (before the birth), and birth weight is measured after delivery. Hence, it is prospective.

Cohort studies are a type of observational study design that follows a group of people (a cohort) over time to assess the outcomes of exposure to certain risk factors or interventions.

Indications to conduct a cohort study:

  • Exposure Assessment
  • Incidence Calculation
  • Time Relationship
  • Rare Exposures
  • Multiple Outcomes
  • Long Latency Period
  • Natural Course

Retrospective cohort (Option B): This would involve looking back at existing records to determine past exposure (e.g., smoking history from medical records) and linking it to outcomes (birth weight).

Case-control study (Option C): This would start with cases (e.g., low birth weight babies) and controls (normal birth weight babies) and then look back to determine maternal smoking history.

Cross-sectional study (Option D): This would assess both exposure (smoking history) and outcome (birth weight) at the same point in time, which is not the case here since birth weight is assessed after delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding prevalence and incidence in relation to a newly introduced drug that reduces mortality but does not cure the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D)  Increase in prevalence

 

Explanation:

 

  • Introduction of a drug that decreases mortality but doesn't cure the disease prolongs the duration of the disease for each individual.
  • Prevalence (P) = Incidence (I) × Duration (D).
  • Since the duration of the disease is prolonged, despite decreased mortality, there will be an increase in prevalence.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Decrease in incidence (Option A): The drug doesn't affect the occurrence of new cases, so incidence isn't necessarily impacted.

 

Decrease in prevalence (Option B): The prolonged duration of the disease may increase prevalence despite decreased mortality.

 

Increase in incidence (Option C): The drug doesn't influence new case occurrence, so incidence isn't necessarily impacted.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between prevalence, incidence, and the introduction of a new drug that reduces mortality but does not provide a cure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option D) Increase in prevalence

 

Explanation: 

  • Prevalence refers to the proportion of individuals in a population who have a particular disease or condition at a specific point in time. If the new drug decreases mortality but does not cure the disease, it means that individuals with the disease are living longer.
  • As a result, the duration of the disease for each individual is prolonged, which may lead to an accumulation of cases over time. This accumulation of cases could potentially result in an increase in the prevalence of the disease. Although the drug may decrease mortality, it does not prevent new cases from occurring, leading to a higher number of individuals with the disease in the population.
  • Therefore, the correct statement is that there would be an increase in prevalence (Option D) due to the prolonged duration of the disease despite the decrease in mortality.

 

Incorrect Choices:

 

  • Decrease in incidence (Option a): Incidence refers to the number of new cases of a disease that occur in a population over a specific period of time. The introduction of a new drug that decreases mortality but does not cure the disease does not directly impact the occurrence of new cases. The drug may improve the survival rate of individuals already diagnosed with the disease, but it does not influence the number of new cases being diagnosed. Therefore, the incidence of the disease would not necessarily decrease as a result of this drug.

 

  • Decrease in prevalence (Option B): Since the drug does not cure the disease but only decreases mortality, it means that individuals with the disease are living longer. However, the prevalence of the disease is influenced by both the number of new cases and the duration of the disease. If the drug does not impact the number of new cases, the overall prevalence of the disease may not decrease.

 

  • Increase in incidence (Option C): Similar to option A, the introduction of a new drug that decreases mortality but does not cure the disease does not directly impact the occurrence of new cases. The drug may improve the survival rate of individuals already diagnosed with the disease, but it does not affect the likelihood of new cases developing. Therefore, the incidence of the disease would not necessarily increase due to the introduction of this drug.

  • Commonly used in epidemiology, public health, and demographic research for comparing mortality rates.

questions.text: What is the most effective study design to demonstrate the relationship between cause and effect among the options listed below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Cohort study

Explanation:

  • Cohort study is the best study design to demonstrate cause and effect relationships.
  • Reasons include:
  • Temporal sequence: Follows individuals over time, establishing exposure preceding outcome.
  • Exposure assessment: Collects detailed exposure information for accurate measurement.
  • Control for confounding: Includes measures to minimize influence of other factors.
  • Large sample size: Enhances statistical power and generalizability.
  • Long-term follow-up: Allows evaluation of short-term and long-term outcomes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Case control study (Option A): Case-control studies are retrospective and rely on recall, not ideal for establishing cause and effect.

Cross-sectional study (Option C): Cross-sectional studies provide snapshot but lack temporal sequence to establish causality.

Clinical trial (Option D): Clinical trials focus on specific treatments, may not address broader cause and effect relationships.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of experimental study -

 


	Blinding
	Randomization
	Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria
	Statistical analysis
questions.solution:
Defining inclusion and exclusion criteria (Step C)

  • Establishes the study population by selecting appropriate participants.

Randomization (Step B)

  • Assigns participants into different groups (e.g., treatment vs. control) to reduce bias.

Blinding (Step A)

  • Ensures that patients, investigators, or data analysts are unaware of group assignments to prevent bias.

Statistical analysis (Step D)

  • After data collection, statistical tests are applied to determine the significance of results.

Therefore, C → B → A → D
(Defining criteria → Randomization → Blinding → Statistical analysis)

This sequence ensures a methodologically sound experimental study that minimizes bias and improves validity.

Steps in an Experimental Study

Experimental studies, such as randomized controlled trials (RCTs), follow a structured process to ensure validity and minimize bias.

Step

Description

1. Defining Inclusion & Exclusion Criteria

Determines which participants are eligible for the study, ensuring a uniform population.

2. Randomization

Randomly assigns participants into groups (e.g., treatment vs. control) to eliminate selection bias.

3. Blinding

Conceals group allocation from participants, investigators, or both to reduce bias.

4. Intervention Implementation

The experimental treatment is administered while maintaining study protocols.

5. Data Collection

Outcome measures are recorded systematically for further analysis.

6. Statistical Analysis

Data is processed using statistical tests to evaluate the treatment effect.

7. Interpretation & Reporting

Findings are interpreted, conclusions are drawn, and results are published.

 

B → C → A → D: Incorrect because randomization cannot occur before defining the study population.

 

A → B → C → D: Incorrect because blinding happens after randomization and selection of participants.

 

C → A → B → D: Incorrect because randomization must occur before blinding to ensure unbiased group assignment.

questions.text: A new drug combination of chemotherapy and immunotherapy for metastatic melanoma was prescribed by a radiotherapist. It prolongs survival. Which of the following is true in this situation?

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases:

  • Incidence: Refers to the number of new cases of a disease occurring in a specific population during a defined time period.
  • Prevalence: Refers to the total number of cases (both new and existing) in a specific population at a given time.

Impact of Prolonging Survival on Incidence and Prevalence:

  1. Incidence:
    • The number of new cases of metastatic melanoma is not affected by the treatment. Therefore, the incidence remains the same.
  2. Prevalence:
    • Prolonging survival means patients live longer with the disease, resulting in an increase in the total number of cases at any given time. Hence, the prevalence increases.

Incidence increases and prevalence reduces (Option A): This is incorrect because prolonging survival does not increase the number of new cases (incidence), and prevalence cannot reduce when survival increases.

Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same (Option B): The new treatment does not affect the occurrence of new cases (incidence), and prolonging survival would increase, not stabilize, prevalence.

Incidence reduces and prevalence increases (Option D): The treatment affects survival, not the occurrence of new cases, so the incidence remains unchanged.

questions.text: What is the most effective quantitative method for examining previous research studies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Meta-analysis

Meta-analysis is considered the most effective quantitative method for examining previous research studies. It involves the statistical combination of results from multiple studies to identify patterns, improve precision, and estimate the overall effect size of a given intervention or exposure.

  1. Meta-analysis combines data from various studies, which increases the statistical power and allows for a more comprehensive conclusion than individual studies alone.
  2. It provides a quantitative summary of the effects, allowing for a clearer understanding of the consistency and strength of findings across different populations or settings.
  3. Systematic reviews, which often precede meta-analysis, are a rigorous method of synthesizing existing research, but meta-analysis takes it a step further by statistically integrating results.

Cohort Study (Option A): This is an observational study design used to follow groups of people over time but is not a method for examining previous research studies.

Systematic Review (Option B): A systematic review is a comprehensive summary of existing research, but it does not necessarily include statistical analysis. It organizes and assesses the quality of existing studies.

RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial) (Option D): An RCT is a primary research design for evaluating interventions but does not deal with summarizing previous research studies.

questions.text:
During the Maha Kumbh Mela, mobile health units and medical bases were set up, along with multiple surveillance units for monitoring cases of fever, diarrhea, and respiratory illnesses.

What was the primary purpose of setting up these surveillance units?

choices.text: To reduce the need for medical professionals
For early diagnosis and detection of potential outbreak warning signs
For immediate quarantine of all symptomatic individuals

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - For early diagnosis and detection of potential outbreak warning signs

Explanation:

Surveillance units track illnesses like fever, diarrhea, and respiratory infections to enable early diagnosis and detect potential outbreak warning signs, helping to prevent widespread transmission.

  • It is the systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data to plan, implement, and evaluate public health practice. (Option B)
  • Types:
    • Active surveillance: Involves proactive data collection with efforts to find cases.
    • Passive surveillance: Relies on routine reporting from healthcare providers or institutions.
    • Sentinel surveillance: Monitors specific sentinel sites or groups for early detection of trends.

Incorrect Options:

To reduce the need for medical professionals (Option A): Surveillance units support, not replace, medical professionals. They rely on trained staff to monitor and respond to health risks.

For immediate quarantine of all symptomatic individuals (Option C): Quarantine is based on confirmed risk, not just symptoms. Surveillance identifies potential outbreaks, but not all symptomatic people need isolation.

To provide curative treatment only (Option D): Surveillance focuses on monitoring and early detection. Treatment is provided by medical units, while surveillance aims to prevent outbreaks.

Often uses medical records, employment logs, or registries. Can be retrospective cohort if subjects are grouped by exposure and followed through past records to see outcomes.

Advantages: Less time-consuming, less expensive than prospective studies.

questions.text: A long-term study found that individuals who had high blood pressure (BP) during childhood continued to have high BP in adulthood, and those with low BP in childhood tended to maintain lower levels later in life. Which of the following epidemiological concepts does this pattern best represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Tracking of blood pressure

Explanation:

  • Tracking of blood pressure refers to the tendency of an individual’s relative position within a distribution (e.g., BP levels) to remain consistent over time. In other words, those with high BP in childhood often remain at the higher end of BP in adulthood, and those with low BP tend to stay lower - even though absolute values may change with age.
  • This concept is important in predicting adult disease risk from childhood measurements and emphasizes early preventive measures.

Rule of halves (Option A): Refers to the observation in hypertension that only half of all hypertensives are diagnosed, half of them are treated, and half of those treated achieve control. It does not describe lifelong consistency in BP levels.

Regression to the mean (Option B): This is a statistical phenomenon where extreme values tend to move closer to the average on subsequent measurements. It does not imply consistent rank ordering over time.

Cohort effect (Option D): Refers to differences in health outcomes between groups born in different time periods due to shared exposures or experiences. It is unrelated to the persistence of BP levels within the same individuals.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with COVID-19 dies in the hospital. Which type of surveillance does this death report fall under?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Passive surveillance

Explanation:

  • In passive surveillance, healthcare providers routinely submit reports to public health authorities based on diagnosed cases or events they encounter in daily practice.
  • A hospital death certificate for a diabetic patient with COVID-19 is an example — the hospital records the death and reports it to health authorities without special prompting or additional case-finding efforts.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Active surveillance: Involves actively seeking out cases through field visits, record reviews, or outreach by public health officials — more resource-intensive and not part of routine passive reporting.

Option C - Sentinel surveillance: Relies on selected health facilities or sites to provide high-quality, detailed data for certain conditions, often for trend monitoring — not a universal reporting system.

Option D - Syndromic surveillance: Focuses on early detection by monitoring symptom patterns (e.g., fever, cough) before a definitive diagnosis is made — this case already has a confirmed cause of death.

questions.text: A study was conducted in 3 states to measure the mean blood pressure in each community. Health workers were assigned to visit each house in the 3 communities. The mean blood pressure of each community was then compared. What is the study design called?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Cross sectional

  • A cross-sectional study involves observing a defined population at a single point in time or over a short period. In this scenario, health workers measured the mean blood pressure of each community at one point in time, making it a cross-sectional study.

Cross-sectional studies:

  • Observations are done only once in the population.
  • Carried over a given point of time or period of time.
  • This helps to find out the existence of both old and new cases (Prevalence rate).
  • This does not help to study the natural history of the disease and the risk factors.
  • This is not time-consuming, not difficult, and cheap.

Incorrect Options:

Case-control (Option A): A case-control study compares individuals who have a specific condition (cases) with individuals who do not have the condition (controls).

Cohort (Option C): A cohort study follows a group of people over time to see how their exposures affect their outcomes.

Ecological study (Option D): An ecological study examines the relationships between exposure and outcome at the population or group level rather than the individual level.

questions.text: A gym owner observes that individuals who drink iced tea during their workouts tend to lose more weight. What is the nature of this relationship?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Indirect

Explanation:

  • In this case, weight loss (outcome) is not directly caused by drinking iced tea (independent variable). A third factor could influence both, like the workout itself.
  • Also, these individuals might be more health-conscious overall, engage in more vigorous workouts, or follow a better diet, which facilitates their weight loss.

Types of Association:

Type of Association

Description

Spurious (Option A)

An association that appears to be present but is actually due to chance or an error in data.

If the gym owner's observation was spurious, it would mean that the association between iced tea consumption and weight loss is completely false and exists due to some error in observation or data collection.

Indirect (Option D)

An association in which a third variable (known as the confounding variable) causes both the predictor and the outcome.

Direct (Causal)  (Option C)

An association where the predictor directly influences the outcome.

 

If the relationship between iced tea consumption and weight loss were direct, it would mean that drinking iced tea itself leads to weight loss. However, it is unlikely that drinking iced tea alone would have a direct effect on weight loss.

a. One-to-One causal

A direct causal link between a single predictor and a single outcome.

b. Multifactorial

An association involving multiple factors contributing to the outcome.

Relative (Option B): This would imply a comparison between two things, but doesn't directly address the relationship type.

questions.text: Blood cholesterol shown as mg/ml value is in which scale?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Continuous

Explanation:

  • Continuous data refers to data that can take any value within a given range and can be measured with a high degree of precision.
  • Continuous data can include decimal values and can theoretically take on an infinite number of possible values within the specified range.
  • Examples of continuous data include height, weight, temperature, and blood cholesterol levels (measured in mg/dL or mmol/L).
  • In the context of blood cholesterol levels, they are measured on a continuous scale because they can take on any value within a range (e.g., from 100 mg/dL to 300 mg/dL) and can be measured with a high degree of precision using laboratory methods.

Incorrect Options:

Ordinal (Option A):

  • Ordinal data refers to data that have a defined order or ranking but the differences between the values are not meaningful or consistent.
  • For example, ranking students based on their exam scores (1st, 2nd, 3rd, etc.) represents ordinal data because while there is a ranking order, the difference in scores between students may not be uniform or meaningful.

Nominal (Option B):

  • Nominal data refers to categorical data where the categories are unordered and have no inherent numerical value.
  • For example, colors (red, blue, green) or types of fruits (apple, banana, orange) represent nominal data because there is no inherent order or ranking among the categories.

Discrete (Option C):

  • Discrete data refers to data that can only take specific, distinct values and cannot take on values between these points. Discrete data are usually counts of items or events and are typically represented by whole numbers.
  • For example, the number of students in a classroom or the number of cars in a parking lot are examples of discrete data.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text:
Calculate relative risk for the given situation:


	
		
			
			 
			
			
			Exposed to malaria
			
			
			Not exposed to malaria
			
		
		
			
			Vaccinated
			
			
			6
			
			
			94
			
		
		
			
			Non-vaccinated
			
			
			12
			
			
			88
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 0.5

Explanation:

Relative risk = Incidence in Vaccinated / Incidence in Non-Vaccinated

Relative risk (RR):

Incidence in Vaccinated (Exposed to Malaria):

  • Number of vaccinated individuals exposed: 6
  • Total vaccinated individuals: 6 (exposed) + 94 (not exposed) = 100
  • Incidence in vaccinated = 6/100 = 0.06 (or 60/1000)

 

Incidence in Non-Vaccinated (Exposed to Malaria):

  • Number of non-vaccinated individuals exposed: 12
  • Total non-vaccinated individuals: 12 (exposed) + 88 (not exposed) = 100
  • Incidence in non-vaccinated = 12/100 = 0.12 (or 120/1000)

Relative Risk (RR):

  • RR = Incidence in Vaccinated / Incidence in Non-Vaccinated
  • RR = 0.06 / 0.12 = 0.5

questions.text: Which among the following cannot be studied using case-control study?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cause to effect

Explanation:

  • Cause to effect cannot be studied using case-control studies and it is studied using a cohort study.
  • In case-control studies, researchers start with individuals who already have the outcome of interest (cases) and compare them to individuals without the outcome (controls).
  • This retrospective design makes it challenging to establish causality because the exposure may have occurred before or after the disease developed, leaving the relationship unclear.
  • Additionally, since participants are not followed over time, the study cannot confirm whether the exposure directly caused the outcome.
  • Thus, case-control studies are more suited for identifying associations rather than proving causal relationships.

Case-Control study:

Advantages

Disadvantages

  • Less time taken.
  • Inexpensive.
  • Minimal ethical problems.
  • Multiple exposure was studied.
  • Rare diseases can be studied.
  • Attrition bias not present
  • Forms the rationale for prevention and control programmes based on risk factors.
  • Selection bias.
  • Recall bias.
  • Interviewer bias.
  • Cannot measure incidence: Only provides estimation of relative risk.
  • Cannot differentiate between causes and associated factors

Incorrect Options:

Effect to cause (Option A): Case-control study precedes backward from effect to cause, hence it is also called effect to cause study.

Rare Disease (Option B): Rare Diseases can be studied using case-control.

Odds ratio (Option C): Odds ratio is used to analyze and interpret the case-control study.

questions.solution:

Explanation:

Histogram (Option B):

Bar Diagram (Option A):

Regression analysis (Option C): It is a statistical technique used to describe relationships between variables. It represents unitary change.

  • It quantifies how changes in one variable are associated with changes in another variable(s).
  • It provides insights into the direction (positive or negative correlation) and strength (the magnitude of the relationship) between variables. (Option A)
  • The process involves fitting a mathematical model to observed data to describe the effect of ≥1 independent variable on a dependent variable. (Option B)

questions.text: According to SDG proposed goals towards 2030, Which of the following is the target for maternal mortality rate reduction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - <70/100000:

  • The SDGs aim to reduce the maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 deaths per 100,000 live births by 2030. This target reflects the global efforts to improve maternal health and reduce the risks associated with childbirth.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - <60/100000: This option is not the correct answer. While reducing the maternal mortality ratio to less than 60 deaths per 100,000 live births is a noble goal, it is not the specific target for maternal mortality reduction set by the SDGs.

Option C - <50/100000: This option is not the correct answer. While further reducing the maternal mortality ratio to less than 50 deaths per 100,000 live births would be an even more ambitious goal, the specific target set by the SDGs is slightly higher.

Option D - <80/100000: This option is not the correct answer. While aiming for a maternal mortality ratio of less than 80 deaths per 100,000 live births would still represent progress, it is not the exact target established by the SDGs for maternal mortality reduction.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about triage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Yellow - stable, need observation:

  • This category is used for patients who are stable but need observation and these patients have injuries or conditions that are not immediately life-threatening but could worsen without proper medical attention. They may require medical care within a reasonable timeframe.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Red-ambulatory: This category is used for patients with severe injuries or conditions requiring immediate attention. These patients are often in critical condition and require immediate medical intervention. It is not indicative of being "ambulatory."

Option C - Black- minor injuries: This category is used for patients who are deceased or have injuries so severe that they are unlikely to survive even with medical intervention. It is not used for "minor injuries."

Option D - Green-life threatening: This category is often used for patients with minor injuries or conditions that are not life-threatening. These patients can wait longer for medical care compared to patients in the other categories. It is not indicative of being "life-threatening."

questions.text: Denominator in incidence rate is?

choices.text: Total population at risk in a year
Total new cases in a year

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Total population at risk in a year:

  • In epidemiology, the incidence rate is a measure of the probability or risk of occurrence of a given medical condition in a population within a specified period. The denominator for incidence rate is the total population at risk during a specific time period (e.g., a year).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Total observed population: This could be misleading as it might include those not at risk of the condition (e.g., already had the condition or immune to it), which is not an appropriate denominator for calculating incidence rate.

Option C - Total live births: This could be used as the denominator when calculating rates for conditions that occur at or around the time of birth, but not for incidence rate of a condition in the general population.

Option D - Total new cases in a year: This is a part of the numerator, not the denominator, when calculating incidence rate. The incidence rate is calculated as the number of new cases (numerator) divided by the total population at risk (denominator), over a specified time.

questions.text: In an experiment 39 was the highest number but was mistaken for 93. It will affect which of the following?

choices.text: Mean will remain same, median will increase
Mean and median both will increase
Mean will increase, median will remain same
Both mean and median will decrease

questions.solution:
Correct Option C-  Mean will increase, median will remain the same:

  • The inclusion of the higher value (93) instead of the original highest value (39) will increase the mean, but the median will remain the same. The median is only affected by the middle value(s) of the dataset, so changing the highest value will not impact the median as long as the middle values remain unchanged.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mean will remain the same, median will increase:  

  • Adding a value (rather than replacing it, like in the scenario) equal to or higher than the highest value to the dataset will cause the mean to remain the same and the median to increase.

Option B - Mean and median both will increase: 

  • For this to happen, a new value higher than the highest value should be added to the existing dataset. 

Option D - Both mean and median will decrease: 

  • This could happen if the highest value(s) in the dataset are removed or replaced by lower values.

questions.text: No. of live births/1000 women in reproductive age group?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - General Fertility Rate:

  • The general fertility rate (GFR) is the number of live births per 1,000 women in the reproductive age group (usually defined as 15-49 years) in a given year. It directly measures the number of live births occurring in a population of women in their reproductive years.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Total Fertility Rate: The total fertility rate (TFR) is a measure of the average number of children that would be born to a woman over her lifetime, assuming she experiences the current age-specific fertility rates throughout her reproductive years. It is not directly related to the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group.

Option C - Net Reproduction Rate: The net reproduction rate (NRR) is a measure of the average number of daughters that would be born to a woman over her lifetime, considering both age-specific fertility rates and mortality rates. It is more focused on population replacement and growth.

Option D - Crude Birth Rate: The crude birth rate is the total number of live births in a given year divided by the total population, usually expressed per 1,000 people. It provides an overall measure of the birth rate in a population but doesn't specifically focus on the reproductive age group.

questions.text: In which phase of clinical trials drug dosing is determined?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phase 1:

  • This phase focuses on evaluating the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a drug in a small group of healthy volunteers or patients. The primary goal is to determine the drug's safety profile and establish an appropriate dose range. Dosing is initially determined based on preclinical data and adjusted as necessary based on observed effects and tolerability in this phase.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Phase 2: In this phase, the drug's efficacy and further safety are assessed in a larger group of patients with the condition the drug is intended to treat. Although dosing strategies may be refined based on efficacy and side effects observed in Phase 2, the initial dose determination is generally established in Phase 1.

Option C - Phase 3: This phase involves large-scale testing of the drug in diverse populations to confirm its effectiveness, monitor side effects, and compare it with existing treatments. While Phase 3 can provide additional data on the optimal dosing regimen and long-term effects, the primary dosing determination occurs in Phase 1.

Option D - Phase 4: This phase, also known as post-marketing surveillance, occurs after the drug has been approved for general use. It focuses on long-term effectiveness, monitoring of adverse effects in the general population, and potential new uses. Dosing is not typically determined in Phase 4 but rather monitored for ongoing safety and effectiveness.

questions.text: Mid-year population is the denominator in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) CDR

Explanation:

  • The crude death rate (CDR) is a demographic indicator that measures the number of deaths in a population per 1,000 individuals per year.

  • It is calculated by dividing the total number of deaths in a given period by the mid-year population and multiplying by 1,000.

CDR = (Number of deaths / Mid-year population) x 1000

  • Therefore, the mid-year population serves as the denominator in calculating the crude death rate. This rate provides a broad overview of mortality within a population, irrespective of age or other factors.

Incorrect Options:

CFR (Option B):

  • The case fatality rate (CFR) is a measure of the proportion of individuals diagnosed with a particular disease or condition who die from that disease or condition within a specified time period.

  • It is calculated by dividing the number of deaths from the disease by the number of diagnosed cases and multiplying by 100 to get a percentage.

  • CFR is commonly used in epidemiology and public health to assess the severity of a disease outbreak or epidemic.

MMR (Option C):

  • The maternal mortality rate (MMR) is a measure of the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births.

  • It reflects the risk associated with childbirth and pregnancy-related complications.

  • MMR is an important indicator of maternal health and healthcare system performance, especially in developing countries where maternal mortality rates tend to be higher.

NMR (Option D):

  • The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) is a measure of the number of deaths among newborns (within the first 28 days of life) per 1,000 live births.

  • It specifically focuses on mortality during the neonatal period, which is critical for assessing the quality of maternal and newborn healthcare services.

  • NMR is an essential indicator for monitoring progress in reducing infant mortality and improving newborn health outcomes.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the single exposure point source epidemic?

choices.text: Has more than one incubation period

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Explosive in nature

Explanation:

  • A single exposure point source epidemic is characterized by a sudden and simultaneous exposure to an infectious agent, leading to an explosive increase in cases within a short time frame, typically seen in foodborne or waterborne outbreaks.

 

Has more than one incubation period (Option A): is incorrect because a single exposure point source epidemic typically results from a single exposure event, leading to cases clustering around a single incubation period.

Has multiple peaks (Option B): is incorrect because a single exposure outbreak usually shows a single sharp peak, not multiple peaks.

Slow rise and fall (Option D): is incorrect because a single exposure point source epidemic exhibits a rapid onset and decline in cases rather than a gradual change.

questions.text: What is the serial interval?

choices.text: Time taken to develop a Primary case A
Time gap between entry of organism till maximum infectivity
Interval between Primary and secondary case
Time gap between onset till first detection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Interval between Primary and secondary case

Explanation:

  • The serial interval is the time between the onset of symptoms in the primary case (the first infected person) and the onset of symptoms in a secondary case (the person infected by the primary case). It is useful for understanding the transmission dynamics of an infectious disease.

 

Time taken to develop a Primary case (Option A): is incorrect because this refers to the incubation period or the time it takes for symptoms to develop after exposure to the pathogen, not the serial interval.

Time gap between entry of organism till maximum infectivity (Option B): is incorrect. This describes the infectious period or incubation period, not the serial interval.

Time gap between onset till first detection (Option D): is incorrect because this refers to the time to diagnosis or detection time, not the serial interval.

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. What type of study is being performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Retrospective cohort study

Explanation:

  • A retrospective cohort study is a combination of a prospective cohort study and a case-control study.
  • The researcher goes back in time and selects study groups from existing past medical records and traces it forward.
  • In this case, past records of the aniline dye handlers were noted to study the close association with bladder cancer.

Retrospective Cohort Study

  • Start study at present time
  • Move backwards (retrospectively) and use historical data
  • Based on historical data, divide study participants into exposed and non exposed groups.
  • Ex: Based on Medical college register of 2010 divide students into exposed and non exposed groups
  • Determine outcomes (diseased and non diseased rates) at the time study begins.
  • They produce faster results than prospective cohort studies.
  • It has been used for the study of lung carcinoma in uranium miners, arsenic in carcinogenesis, angiosarcoma of the liver, and radiation exposure in physicians.

 

 

Prospective cohort study (Option B):

  • In this study, the disease has not yet occurred when the investigation has started.
  • The investigation starts from the present and proceeds to the future.
  • A few examples are study on smoking and lung cancer, study of oral contraceptives and health.

Case-control study (Option C):

  • It starts with the disease and, hence it proceeds from effect to cause.
  • Quicker results are noticed.
  • It is suitable for the study of rare diseases and is relatively cheap.

Intervention and response (Option D):

  • It is also called an experimental study.
  • Intervention and response involves direct control over study, unlike cohort studies which are observational.

questions.text:
Match the following columns on Epidemiology Guidelines:


	
		
			
			A. Care
			
			
			1. RCT
			
		
		
			
			B. Consort
			
			
			2. Case report
			
		
		
			
			C. Prisma
			
			
			3. Observational study
			
		
		
			
			D. Strobe/Moose
			
			
			4. Systematic Review
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) A2-B1-C4-D3

Explanation:

Care:

  • Stands for Case Report.
  • It is a guideline that provides a framework for reporting case reports in medical and health-related fields.
  • Case reports describe and analyze individual cases or small groups of cases, providing valuable insights into rare diseases, unusual presentations of common diseases, and unexpected treatment outcomes.

Consort:

  • Stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • It is a guideline designed to improve the transparency and reporting of randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
  • It provides a checklist and flow diagram to ensure that essential information about the design, conduct, analysis, and interpretation of RCTs is reported in a standardised and comprehensive manner.

Prisma:

  • Stands for Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses. It is a guideline that aims to improve the transparency and reporting of systematic reviews and meta-analyses.
  • PRISMA provides a checklist and flow diagram to ensure that researchers accurately report their systematic reviews and meta-analyses' methods, results, and interpretations.

Strobe/Moose:

  • STROBE stands for Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology, while MOOSE stands for Meta-analysis of Observational Studies in Epidemiology.
  • These guidelines provide recommendations for reporting observational studies, including cohort, case-control, and cross-sectional studies.
  • STROBE and MOOSE guidelines help researchers ensure that they report relevant information about the design, conduct, analysis, and interpretation of observational studies, thus enhancing the transparency and reproducibility of their findings.

questions.text: A longitudinal, observational, and analytical study is also known as?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Cohort Study

Explanation:

The combination of a longitudinal, observational, and analytical study is known as a Cohort Study.

  • Design: Prospective study following a group of individuals with a common characteristic or exposure over time.

  • A cohort study is an observational analytical study that provides evidence supporting the existence of an association between exposure and outcome.

questions.text: In a hospital pharmacy setting, a budget of 50,000 Rs is allocated for the purchase of three types of drugs: 35,000 Rs for A drugs, 10,000 Rs for B drugs, and the remaining amount for C drugs. Which type of analysis is being used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - ABC Analysis:

ABC Analysis is a technique used to classify items based on their value or importance within an inventory or resource allocation context. It categorizes items into three groups:

  • A Items: These are items that are of high value or importance but typically represent a smaller portion of the total items. In the context of the question, A drugs receive the largest allocation of the budget (35,000 Rs), and they would be classified as "A Items" in an ABC analysis due to their high value.
  • B Items: These are items of moderate value or importance and constitute a moderate portion of the total items. B drugs receive a budget of 10,000 Rs, which is less than A drugs but still represents a considerable portion of the total budget. They would be classified as "B Items" in an ABC analysis.
  • C Items: These are items of lower value or importance and typically make up a larger portion of the total items. In the question, the remaining amount after allocating for A and B drugs is meant for C drugs. Since the remaining amount is smaller, C drugs would be classified as "C Items" in an ABC analysis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Network Analysis: Network analysis involves the study of interconnected activities and their relationships in a project or process. It's used to optimize scheduling and resource allocation in complex projects. This option is not applicable to the scenario described in the question.

Option C - VED Analysis: VED Analysis is used in inventory management to categorize items into three groups based on their criticality:

  • V (Vital) Items: These are items that are essential for the operation and should be available at all times to avoid disruptions. This analysis doesn't directly apply to the allocation of a budget among different types of drugs.
  • E (Essential) Items: These are important items but may have alternatives or substitutes available. They are not as critical as Vital items.
  • D (Desirable) Items: These are items with relatively lower criticality, and their absence might not significantly impact operations.

Option D - System Analysis: System Analysis involves studying complex systems to identify their components, relationships, and functions, usually to optimize the system's performance or design. This option is not relevant to the scenario described in the question.

questions.text: Calculate the infant mortality rate of a town with a population of 20,000, based on the following data: In a year, there were a total of 456 births, out of which 56 were stillborn. The total number of deaths was 247, with 56 deaths occurring within 28 days of life, and an additional 34 deaths occurring after 28 days but before completing the first birthday. Calculate the infant mortality rate of the area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 225:

  • Calculation of Infant Mortality Rate (IMR):
    • Total population: 20,000
    • Total live births: 456
    • Total deaths: 247
    • Deaths within 28 days of life(Neonatal deaths): 56
    • Deaths after 28 days but before completing the first birthday(Number of Post- Neonatal Deaths): 34
  • To calculate the IMR:
    • IMR = (Total infant deaths / Total live births) x 1,000
    • Total Live Births=Total Births−Still born Births=456−56=400
    • Total Infant Deaths=Number of Neonatal Deaths + Number of Post-Neonatal Deaths=56+34=90
    • IMR = 90 / 400 x 1,000
    • IMR ≈ 225
  • Therefore, the infant mortality rate of the area is approximately 225 per 1,000 live births.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect: 197 - Does not match the calculated infant mortality rate.

questions.text: During a study, one group (group A) was administered a placebo, while another group (group B) was given a new medication. In group A, 36 out of 120 patients died, whereas in group B, 26 out of 130 patients died. How many patients need to be treated in order to prevent one death?

  • To calculate the number needed to treat (NNT) to avert 1 death, we use the formula NNT = 1 / (Risk Difference). In this case, the Risk Difference is 0.1, calculated by subtracting the mortality rate in the treated group (26/130) from that in the control group (36/120).

  • So, NNT = 1 / 0.1 = 10. Therefore, 10 patients need to be treated to avert 1 death.

Incorrect Options:
